IronWASP Security Analysis Report
Report based on the analysis performed by the open source web security software, IronWASP
Overview
Index
http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Overview
This report contains the list of security findings discovered by IronWASP. The current section of the report gives a brief overview of the number of different findings, the numbers are categorized by the hosts they were discovered on.
The index section contains the names of all the findings. The sections after that show details of every individual finding.

The table below shows the number of findings discovered in each host. The findings are seperated based on their type and severity.


Legend:

High     High Severity Vulnerability
Medium     Medium Severity Vulnerability
Low     Low Severity Vulnerability
Info     Information Findings
Test Leads     Things of interest for manual testing

The High, Medium and Low severity vulnerability numbers are also split based on the confidence with which IronWASP has reported them.

  0      High Confidence                0      Medium Confidence                0      Low Confidence             

High Medium Low Info Test leads Total Hosts
200
242
1
2
13
458
http://127.0.0.1:8080/
51

2

0

1
0
0
Index
The titles of all the findings are listed below categorized by the host they were discovered on. All items in the list below are links to relevant sections in the report.

  • Cookie BenchmarkTest01000 may contain sensitive information
    1. /benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01000
  • Cookie BenchmarkTest01877 may contain sensitive information
    1. /benchmark/sqli-04/BenchmarkTest01877
  • Cookie SomeCookie may contain sensitive information
    1. /benchmark/securecookie-00/BenchmarkTest00348
http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Command Injection Found
>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00480
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00480
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00480 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5089 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 21 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00480 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest00480=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest00480=Movies&BenchmarkTest00480=Writing&BenchmarkTest00480=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5089milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5112 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 21 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00480 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest00480=%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest00480=Movies&BenchmarkTest00480=Writing&BenchmarkTest00480=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5112milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ECHOOO&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5094 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 21 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00731
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00731
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00731 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5102 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 26 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00731 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=hhh&productID=hhh&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest00731=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5102milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5106 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 26 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00816?username=qqqq&password=qqqq&BenchmarkTest00816=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00816
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00816 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5098 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 21 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5098milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5095 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 21 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00815 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5092 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 18 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01285 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=yyyyy&productID=yyyyy&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01285=%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5105milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ls&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5090 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 26 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01285 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=yyyyy&productID=yyyyy&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01285=ls%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5090milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent ls| ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5099 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 26 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01270
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01270
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01270 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5097 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 23 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01270 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=yyyyy&productID=yyyyy&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01270=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5097milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5097 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 23 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01270 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=yyyyy&productID=yyyyy&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01270=%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5097milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ECHOOO&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5095 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 23 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:

If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01286
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01286
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01286 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5101 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 31 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01286 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest01286=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest01286=Movies&BenchmarkTest01286=Writing&BenchmarkTest01286=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5101milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5094 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 31 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:

After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5092 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 17 milliseconds. Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

email=oooo&password=oooo&BenchmarkTest01517=%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5100milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ECHOOO&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5091 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 21 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01517 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

email=oooo&password=oooo&BenchmarkTest01517=ECHOOO%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5091milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01601?username=cc&password=cc&BenchmarkTest01601=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01601
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01601 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5097 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 28 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01601?username=cc&password=cc&BenchmarkTest01601=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5097milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5096 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 28 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01674?username=lll&password=lll&BenchmarkTest01674=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01674
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01674 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5095 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01674?username=lll&password=lll&BenchmarkTest01674=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5095milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5093 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01673
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01673 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5097 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 20 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ls&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5109 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02146 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest02146=ls%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest02146=Movies&BenchmarkTest02146=Writing&BenchmarkTest02146=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5109milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent ls| ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5099 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02249
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02249
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02249 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5096 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02249 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

email=dd&password=dd&BenchmarkTest02249=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5096milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5101 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

Command Injection Found

Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02244
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02244
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02244 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5093 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02244 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

email=dd&password=dd&BenchmarkTest02244=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5093milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5100 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02250 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5094 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.

To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Description:

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02243?username=dd&password=dd&BenchmarkTest02243=ECHOOO%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5096milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent ECHOOO| ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5111 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5111milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02251
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02251
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02251 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5118 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 28 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02251 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest02251=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest02251=Movies&BenchmarkTest02251=Writing&BenchmarkTest02251=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5118milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5106 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 28 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02251 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest02251=%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest02251=Movies&BenchmarkTest02251=Writing&BenchmarkTest02251=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5106milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent localhost&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5088 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 28 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02412?username=yyyyy&password=yyyyy&BenchmarkTest02412=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02412
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02412 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5107 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 17 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02412?username=yyyyy&password=yyyyy&BenchmarkTest02412=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5107milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5107 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 17 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02414 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5096 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 31 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=yyyyy&productID=yyyyy&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest02414=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5096milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02429 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=yyyyy&productID=yyyyy&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest02429=localhost%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5100milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 4:
IronWASP sent localhost| ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5090 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 30 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02429 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=yyyyy&productID=yyyyy&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest02429=localhost%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5090milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00480
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00480
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00480 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5102 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 25 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00480 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 133

BenchmarkTest00480=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest00480=Movies&BenchmarkTest00480=Writing&BenchmarkTest00480=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5102milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5095 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 25 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00480 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 130

BenchmarkTest00480=%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest00480=Movies&BenchmarkTest00480=Writing&BenchmarkTest00480=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5095milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ECHOOO&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5106 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 25 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00731
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00731
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00731 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5090 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 20 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00731 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 82

secure=vvvvv&productID=vvvvv&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest00731=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5090milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5094 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 20 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
