Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00815?username=aa&password=aa&BenchmarkTest00815=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00815
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00815 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5095 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 20 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00815?username=aa&password=aa&BenchmarkTest00815=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5095milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5112 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 20 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

Type:Vulnerability

Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00816?username=aa&password=aa&BenchmarkTest00816=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00816
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00816 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5098 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 28 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00816?username=aa&password=aa&BenchmarkTest00816=ECHOOO%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5096milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01285
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01285
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01285 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5097 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 28 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01285 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 78

secure=mmm&productID=mmm&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01285=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5097milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5107 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 28 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01270
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01270
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01270 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5097 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 20 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01270 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 78

secure=mmm&productID=mmm&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01270=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5097milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5112 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 20 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5094 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 28 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01601?username=rrrr&password=rrrr&BenchmarkTest01601=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01601
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01601 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5092 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01601?username=rrrr&password=rrrr&BenchmarkTest01601=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5092milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5114 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01601?username=rrrr&password=rrrr&BenchmarkTest01601=%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5114milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ECHOOO&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5105 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)

It took 5105milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01674?username=rrrr&password=rrrr&BenchmarkTest01674=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01674
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01674 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5105 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 26 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01674?username=rrrr&password=rrrr&BenchmarkTest01674=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5105milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5093 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 26 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:

If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-01/BenchmarkTest01673?username=rrrr&password=rrrr&BenchmarkTest01673=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01673
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest01673 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5094 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02146
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02146
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02146 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5100 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02146 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 133

BenchmarkTest02146=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest02146=Movies&BenchmarkTest02146=Writing&BenchmarkTest02146=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5100milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5114 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

Host: 127.0.0.1:8080

Content-Length: 130

The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02244 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 66

email=bb&password=bb&BenchmarkTest02244=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5082milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5094 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 23 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02244 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 63

email=bb&password=bb&BenchmarkTest02244=%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5094milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ECHOOO&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5085 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 23 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.

To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02243?username=bb&password=bb&BenchmarkTest02243=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02243
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02243 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5100 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 23 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02243?username=bb&password=bb&BenchmarkTest02243=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5100milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5088 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 23 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02249
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02249
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02249 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5090 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 19 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02249 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 66

email=bb&password=bb&BenchmarkTest02249=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5090milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5095 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 19 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02251
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02251
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02251 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5093 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02251 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 133

BenchmarkTest02251=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost&BenchmarkTest02251=Movies&BenchmarkTest02251=Writing&BenchmarkTest02251=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5093milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5095 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 24 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02412?username=kkk&password=kkk&BenchmarkTest02412=ECHOOO
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02412
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02412 parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5103 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02412?username=kkk&password=kkk&BenchmarkTest02412=%7c+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5106milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent ECHOOO&& ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5089 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 22 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02412?username=kkk&password=kkk&BenchmarkTest02412=ECHOOO%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)



Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5089milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02414
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02414
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02414 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5098 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 27 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02414 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 78

secure=kkk&productID=kkk&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest02414=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5098milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5095 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 27 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Command Injection Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02429
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest02429
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Command Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest02429 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Command Injection is an issue where it is possible to inject and execute operating system commands on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent && ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5092 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 31 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains a system command which if executed will cause the response to be delayed by 5000 milliseconds. The system command is: ping -n 6 localhost

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/cmdi-02/BenchmarkTest02429 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 78

secure=kkk&productID=kkk&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest02429=%26%26+ping+-n+6+localhost

Information about the Response from the Server:

It took 5092milliseconds to recieve the response from the server. It took so long because of the 5000 millisecond delay caused by the payload.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent | ping -n 6 localhost as payload to the application. This payload has a small system command - ping -n 6 localhost. If this command is executed then the server will ping itself 6 times. This will cause the response to be returned around 5000 milliseconds later than usual. After the payload was injected the response from the application took 5083 milliseconds. Normally this particular request is processed at around 31 milliseconds. This indicates that the injected command could have been executed on the server-side.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can manually inject the same payload but by changing the number of ping requests sent to different values. Then you can observe if the time taken for the response to be returned is affected accordingly.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00024
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00024
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00024 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - bar' and 8=8--
Payload B - bar' and 7=5--
Payload C - bar' and 7=7--
Payload D - bar' and 5=8--
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the AND keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 8=8-- which evaluates to true. The payload is bar' and 8=8--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00024 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest00024=bar'+and+8%3d8--&BenchmarkTest00024=Movies&BenchmarkTest00024=Writing&BenchmarkTest00024=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 7=5-- which evaluates to false. The payload is bar' and 7=5--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00024 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest00024=bar'+and+7%3d5--&BenchmarkTest00024=Movies&BenchmarkTest00024=Writing&BenchmarkTest00024=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 7=7-- which evaluates to true. The payload is bar' and 7=7--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00024 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest00024=bar'+and+7%3d7--&BenchmarkTest00024=Movies&BenchmarkTest00024=Writing&BenchmarkTest00024=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 5=8-- which evaluates to false. The payload is bar' and 5=8--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00024 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest00024=bar'+and+5%3d8--&BenchmarkTest00024=Movies&BenchmarkTest00024=Writing&BenchmarkTest00024=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - bar' and 's'='s
Payload B - bar' and 's'='r
Payload C - bar' and 't'='t
Payload D - bar' and 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the AND keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 's'='s which evaluates to true. The payload is bar' and 's'='s

Host: 127.0.0.1:8080

Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00034
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00034
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00034 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - barxxx' or 8=8--
Payload B - barxxx' or 7=5--
Payload C - barxxx' or 7=7--
Payload D - barxxx' or 5=8--
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 8=8-- which evaluates to true. The payload is barxxx' or 8=8--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00034 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest00034=barxxx'+or+8%3d8--&BenchmarkTest00034=Movies&BenchmarkTest00034=Writing&BenchmarkTest00034=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 7=5-- which evaluates to false. The payload is barxxx' or 7=5--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00034 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 7=7-- which evaluates to true. The payload is barxxx' or 7=7--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00034 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest00034=barxxx'+or+7%3d7--&BenchmarkTest00034=Movies&BenchmarkTest00034=Writing&BenchmarkTest00034=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 5=8-- which evaluates to false. The payload is barxxx' or 5=8--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00034 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

BenchmarkTest00034=barxxx'+or+5%3d8--&BenchmarkTest00034=Movies&BenchmarkTest00034=Writing&BenchmarkTest00034=Singing&foo=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Reason 2:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - bar' and 8=8--
Payload B - bar' and 7=5--
Payload C - bar' and 7=7--
Payload D - bar' and 5=8--
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the AND keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'and' followed by the SQL condition 8=8-- which evaluates to true. The payload is bar' and 8=8--

Reason 3:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - bar' and 's'='s
Payload B - bar' and 's'='r
Payload C - bar' and 't'='t
Payload D - bar' and 't'='r
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the AND keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:

If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00428
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00428
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00428 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - barxxx' or 8=8--
Payload B - barxxx' or 7=5--
Payload C - barxxx' or 7=7--
Payload D - barxxx' or 5=8--
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 8=8-- which evaluates to true. The payload is barxxx' or 8=8--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00428 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080

Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

email=zzzzz&password=zzzzz&BenchmarkTest00428=bar'+and+'t'%3d'r

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00429
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00429
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the BenchmarkTest00429 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reasons:
Reason 1:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - barxxx' or 8=8--
Payload B - barxxx' or 7=5--
Payload C - barxxx' or 7=7--
Payload D - barxxx' or 5=8--
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 8=8-- which evaluates to true. The payload is barxxx' or 8=8--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00429 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=vvvvv&productID=vvvvv&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest00429=barxxx'+or+8%3d8--

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 7=5-- which evaluates to false. The payload is barxxx' or 7=5--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00429 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=vvvvv&productID=vvvvv&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest00429=barxxx'+or+7%3d5--

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 7=7-- which evaluates to true. The payload is barxxx' or 7=7--

Information about the Response from the Server:
