SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02653?username=vvvvv&password=vvvvv&BenchmarkTest02653=bar
Affected Parameter:JSESSIONID
Parameter Location:Cookie
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the JSESSIONID parameter of the Cookie section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent three payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - 1'||'A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745
Payload B - 1'+'A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745
Payload C - 1' 'A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745
Payload A is trying to concatenate two strings as per the SQL syntax of Oracle database servers. Payload B is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per SQL syntax of MS SQL database servers. Payload C is trying to concatenate the same two strings as per the SQL syntax of MySQL database servers.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and is different from the response received for Payloads B. This indicates that the application was actually trying to perform the string concatenation on the server-side and that the backend database in use is MS SQL. Since incase of MS SQL database server Payloads A & C would have simply thrown an invalid SQL syntax exception their responses are similar. And Payload B would have executed without this error and so its response was different than the other two.
If the application was not actually performing the concatenation then all three payload should have received very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the three payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with different strings and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per Oracle database's syntax. The payload is 1'||'A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02653?username=vvvvv&password=vvvvv&BenchmarkTest02653=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1'||'A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used MySQL database's concatenation syntax

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MS SQL database's syntax. The payload is 1'+'A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02653?username=vvvvv&password=vvvvv&BenchmarkTest02653=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1'+'A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the responses recieved for the payloads that used MySQL and Oracle databases' concatenation syntax.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to concatenate two strings as per MySQL database's syntax. The payload is 1' 'A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02653?username=vvvvv&password=vvvvv&BenchmarkTest02653=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1'%20'A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is different from the response recieved for the payloads that used MS SQL database's concatenation syntax but similar to the response for the payload that used Oracle database's concatenation syntax

SQL Injection Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02729
Affected Parameter:productID
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
SQL Injection was identified in the productID parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

SQL Injection is an issue where it is possible execute SQL queries on the database being used on the server-side. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application with SQL code snippets in them.
Payload A - kkkxxx" or 8=8--
Payload B - kkkxxx" or 7=5--
Payload C - kkkxxx" or 7=7--
Payload D - kkkxxx" or 5=8--
Payload A and C have a boolean condition after the OR keyword that will evaluate to true. The boolean condition in Payload B and D would evaluate to false.
The response for Payload A and C were similar to each other and were different from the response received for Payload B and D. This indicates that the application was actually evaluating the boolean condition in the payloads. So since Payload A and C both has a true boolean condition their responses are similar, C and D had a false boolean condition.
If the application was not actually evaluating the boolean condition then all four payload should have returned very similar responses. Therefore this indicates that SQL syntax from the payload is executed as part of the SQL query on the server.
False Positive Check Assistance:
Manually analyze the responses received for the four payloads and confirm if the type of similarity explained above actually exists in them. Try resending the same payloads again but with values in the boolean expression and check if this behaviour is repeated.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 8=8-- which evaluates to true. The payload is kkkxxx" or 8=8--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02729 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

secure=kkk&productID=kkkxxx%22+or+8%3d8--&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest02729=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 7=5-- which evaluates to false. The payload is kkkxxx" or 7=5--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02729 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

secure=kkk&productID=kkkxxx%22+or+7%3d5--&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest02729=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the first boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the second boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 7=7-- which evaluates to true. The payload is kkkxxx" or 7=7--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02729 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

secure=kkk&productID=kkkxxx%22+or+7%3d7--&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest02729=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean true condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean true condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean false condition payloads.

Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request contains the conditional operator 'or' followed by the SQL condition 5=8-- which evaluates to false. The payload is kkkxxx" or 5=8--

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02729 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

secure=kkk&productID=kkkxxx%22+or+5%3d8--&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest02729=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

This response is the result of the second boolean false condition based payload. This response is equal to the response of the first boolean false condition payload and different from the responses of the boolean true condition payloads.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Low
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01084
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01084
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the BenchmarkTest01084 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../bar
Payload B - aa../bar
Payload C - bb/../bar
Payload D - bb../bar

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file bar by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file bar normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file bar inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the bar file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../bar

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01084 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

answer=yyyyy&BenchmarkTest01084=aa%2f..%2fbar

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the bar file. The payload is aa../bar

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01084 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

answer=yyyyy&BenchmarkTest01084=aa..%2fbar

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the bar file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../bar

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01084 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

answer=yyyyy&BenchmarkTest01084=bb%2f..%2fbar

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the bar file. The payload is bb../bar

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01084 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

answer=yyyyy&BenchmarkTest01084=bb..%2fbar

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01383?username=aa&password=aa&BenchmarkTest01383=bar
Affected Parameter:User-Agent
Parameter Location:Headers
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the User-Agent parameter of the Headers section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)
Payload B - aa../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)
Payload C - bb/../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)
Payload D - bb../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0) by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0) normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0) inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0) file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01383?username=aa&password=aa&BenchmarkTest01383=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: aa/../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0) file. The payload is aa../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01383?username=aa&password=aa&BenchmarkTest01383=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: aa../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0) file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01383?username=aa&password=aa&BenchmarkTest01383=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: bb/../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0) file. The payload is bb../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01383?username=aa&password=aa&BenchmarkTest01383=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: bb../Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Low
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-03/BenchmarkTest01473
Affected Parameter:answer
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the answer parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\nnnn
Payload B - aa..\nnnn
Payload C - bb\..\nnnn
Payload D - bb..\nnnn

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file nnnn by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file nnnn normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file nnnn inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the nnnn file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa\..\nnnn

Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

answer=aa%5c..%5cnnnn&BenchmarkTest01473=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the nnnn file. The payload is aa..\nnnn

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-03/BenchmarkTest01473 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

answer=aa..%5cnnnn&BenchmarkTest01473=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the nnnn file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb\..\nnnn

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-03/BenchmarkTest01473 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

answer=bb%5c..%5cnnnn&BenchmarkTest01473=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the nnnn file. The payload is bb..\nnnn

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-03/BenchmarkTest01473 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

answer=bb..%5cnnnn&BenchmarkTest01473=bar

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-05/BenchmarkTest02450
Affected Parameter:foo
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the foo parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\bar
Payload B - aa..\bar
Payload C - bb\..\bar
Payload D - bb..\bar

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file bar by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file bar normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file bar inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the bar file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa\..\bar

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the bar file. The payload is aa..\bar

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-05/BenchmarkTest02450 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-01/BenchmarkTest00838?username=qqqq&password=qqqq&BenchmarkTest00838=bar
Affected Parameter:JSESSIONID
Parameter Location:Cookie
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the JSESSIONID parameter of the Cookie section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa\..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745
Payload B - aa..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745
Payload C - bb\..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745
Payload D - bb..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file 1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745 by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ..\. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file 1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745 normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file 1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745 inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ..\ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the 1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745 file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa\..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-01/BenchmarkTest00838?username=qqqq&password=qqqq&BenchmarkTest00838=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=aa\..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the 1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745 file. The payload is aa..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-01/BenchmarkTest00838?username=qqqq&password=qqqq&BenchmarkTest00838=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=aa..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the 1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745 file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb\..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-01/BenchmarkTest00838?username=qqqq&password=qqqq&BenchmarkTest00838=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=bb\..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the 1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745 file. The payload is bb..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-01/BenchmarkTest00838?username=qqqq&password=qqqq&BenchmarkTest00838=bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=bb..\1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Local File Include Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02728
Affected Parameter:Content-Type
Parameter Location:Headers
Description:
Local File Include/Path Traversal was identified in the Content-Type parameter of the Headers section of the scanned request.

Local File Include is an issue where it is possible to load and view the raw contents of any files present on the web server. For more details on this issue refer https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - aa/../application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Payload B - aa../application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Payload C - bb/../application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Payload D - bb../application/x-www-form-urlencoded

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to the file application/x-www-form-urlencoded by including an imaginary directory in the path (aa & bb) but then also invalidating it by traversing upwards by one directory using ../. So these payloads must have the same effect as referring to the file application/x-www-form-urlencoded normally.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They refer to the file application/x-www-form-urlencoded inside invalid directories (aa & bb).
If the application is vulnerable to Local File Include then the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D. The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by adding one more invalid directory and one more ../ to invalidate that directory. This must get the same response as the responses for A & C.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the application/x-www-form-urlencoded file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'aa'. The payload is aa/../application/x-www-form-urlencoded

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02728 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: aa/../application/x-www-form-urlencoded
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'aa' and so does not refer to the application/x-www-form-urlencoded file. The payload is aa../application/x-www-form-urlencoded

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02728 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: aa../application/x-www-form-urlencoded
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload refers to the application/x-www-form-urlencoded file by doing a proper upward directory traversal of a dummy directory 'bb'. The payload is bb/../application/x-www-form-urlencoded

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02728 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: bb/../application/x-www-form-urlencoded
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload does not do a proper upward directory traversal of the dummy directory 'bb' and so does not refer to the application/x-www-form-urlencoded file. The payload is bb../application/x-www-form-urlencoded

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02728 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Type: bb../application/x-www-form-urlencoded
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01305
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest01305
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the BenchmarkTest01305 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They both refer to ports 65533 and 65534 on the server which are valid ports.
If the application is vulnerable to SSRF then it will try to connect to these ports and connections to invalid ports with throw an exception of different type than the exception or error caused by connecting to the valid ports 65533 and 65534 which are most likely to be closed.
This would mean that the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by chaning the port number to some other invalid port and change payloads B & D to some other valid port numbers and check of the four response show the same pattern as before.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 65555 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65555

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01305 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=zzzzz&productID=zzzzz&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01305=localhost%3a65555

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65533 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65533

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01305 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=zzzzz&productID=zzzzz&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01305=localhost%3a65533

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 66666 on localhost. The payload is localhost:66666

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01305 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=zzzzz&productID=zzzzz&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01305=localhost%3a66666

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65534 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65534

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-02/BenchmarkTest01305 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=zzzzz&productID=zzzzz&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest01305=localhost%3a65534

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02650?username=dd&password=dd&BenchmarkTest02650=bar
Affected Parameter:username
Parameter Location:Query
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the username parameter of the Query section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They both refer to ports 65533 and 65534 on the server which are valid ports.
If the application is vulnerable to SSRF then it will try to connect to these ports and connections to invalid ports with throw an exception of different type than the exception or error caused by connecting to the valid ports 65533 and 65534 which are most likely to be closed.
This would mean that the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by chaning the port number to some other invalid port and change payloads B & D to some other valid port numbers and check of the four response show the same pattern as before.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.

Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-06/BenchmarkTest02729

Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the secure parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Server Side Request Forgery Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:Medium
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-05/BenchmarkTest02535
Affected Parameter:foo
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Server Side Request Forgery was identified in the foo parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.

Server Side Request Forgery is an issue where it is possible to forge an HTTP request on the server-side by sending the url in a request. For more details on this issue refer http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/918.html

Reasons:
IronWASP has reported this issue because of the following reason:
Reason:
IronWASP sent four payloads to the application.
Payload A - localhost:65555
Payload B - localhost:65533
Payload C - localhost:66666
Payload D - localhost:65534

Payloads A and C are similar in nature. They both refer to ports 65555 and 66666 on the server which are invalid ports.
Payloads B and D are similar to each other but different from A & C. They both refer to ports 65533 and 65534 on the server which are valid ports.
If the application is vulnerable to SSRF then it will try to connect to these ports and connections to invalid ports with throw an exception of different type than the exception or error caused by connecting to the valid ports 65533 and 65534 which are most likely to be closed.
This would mean that the response for Payloads A & C must be similar to each other and different from responses for Payloads B&D.

The responses for the injected payloads were analyzed and it was found that Payloads A & C got a similar looking response and were also different from responses got from Payloads B & D, thereby indicating the presence of this vulnerability.
False Positive Check Assistance:
To check if this was a valid case or a false positive you can first manually look at the responses received for Payloads A, B, C and D. Analyze these payloads and verify if indeed A & C got similar responses and were different from B & D. You can also change the payloads for A & C by chaning the port number to some other invalid port and change payloads B & D to some other valid port numbers and check of the four response show the same pattern as before.
If you discover that this issue was a false positive then please consider reporting this to lava@ironwasp.org. Your feedback will help improve the accuracy of the scanner.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check explained in this reason section are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 65555 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65555

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-05/BenchmarkTest02535 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

BenchmarkTest02535=bar&BenchmarkTest02535=Movies&BenchmarkTest02535=Writing&BenchmarkTest02535=Singing&foo=localhost%3a65555

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65533 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65533

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-05/BenchmarkTest02535 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

BenchmarkTest02535=bar&BenchmarkTest02535=Movies&BenchmarkTest02535=Writing&BenchmarkTest02535=Singing&foo=localhost%3a65533

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the previous trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger after the next.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the invalid port 66666 on localhost. The payload is localhost:66666

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-05/BenchmarkTest02535 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

BenchmarkTest02535=bar&BenchmarkTest02535=Movies&BenchmarkTest02535=Writing&BenchmarkTest02535=Singing&foo=localhost%3a66666

Information about the Response from the Server:

The contents of this response are different from the response of the next trigger but are similar to the response of the trigger before the previous.

Request sent by Scanner:

This payload points to the valid port 65534 on localhost. The payload is localhost:65534

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/sqli-05/BenchmarkTest02535 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745

BenchmarkTest02535=bar&BenchmarkTest02535=Movies&BenchmarkTest02535=Writing&BenchmarkTest02535=Singing&foo=localhost%3a65534

Cross-site Scripting Detected
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:High
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/xss-01/BenchmarkTest00711
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00711
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
Cross-site Scripting was identified in the BenchmarkTest00711 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request.
The relevant parts of the requests/responses pairs associated with the check that discovered this issue are available below.
Request sent by Scanner:

The payload in this request tries to inject an HTML tag named 'h' with attribute name 'xhx' and attribute value 'yhy'. The payload is <h xhx=yhy>

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/xss-01/BenchmarkTest00711 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796

secure=qqqq&productID=qqqq&foo=foo&BenchmarkTest00711=%3ch+xhx%3dyhy%3e

Response from the Server:

This response contains an HTML tag named 'h' with attribute name 'xhx' and attribute value 'yhy'. This was inserted by the payload.

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Date: Sun, 05 May 2024 14:53:00 GMT

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>
<p>Formatted like: a and <h xhx=yhy>.
</p>
</body>
</html>

Cookie BenchmarkTest00959 missing the HttpOnly flag
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:High
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/ldapi-00/BenchmarkTest00959
Description:
The HttpOnly flag was missing on the cookie: BenchmarkTest00959. This may allow an attacker to get the cookie information using XSS attacks.
Analyzed Response:

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Set-Cookie: BenchmarkTest00959=Ms+Bar; Max-Age=180; Expires=Sun, 05 May 2024 10:49:04 GMT; Domain=127.0.0.1; Path=/benchmark/ldapi-00/BenchmarkTest00959; Secure; SameSite=Strict
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

Affected Url:/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00090
Description:
The HttpOnly flag was missing on the cookie: BenchmarkTest00090. This may allow an attacker to get the cookie information using XSS attacks.
Analyzed Response:

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Set-Cookie: BenchmarkTest00090=ls; Max-Age=180; Expires=Sun, 05 May 2024 10:49:04 GMT; Domain=127.0.0.1; Path=/benchmark/cmdi-00/BenchmarkTest00090; Secure; SameSite=Strict

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/pathtraver-00/BenchmarkTest00065
Description:
The HttpOnly flag was missing on the cookie: BenchmarkTest00065. This may allow an attacker to get the cookie information using XSS attacks.
Analyzed Response:

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

Affected Url:/benchmark/xpathi-00/BenchmarkTest01893
Description:
The HttpOnly flag was missing on the cookie: BenchmarkTest01893. This may allow an attacker to get the cookie information using XSS attacks.
Analyzed Response:

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Set-Cookie: BenchmarkTest01893=2222; Max-Age=180; Expires=Sun, 05 May 2024 10:49:05 GMT; Domain=127.0.0.1; Path=/benchmark/xpathi-00/BenchmarkTest01893; Secure; SameSite=Strict
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 1100

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Set-Cookie: BenchmarkTest01824=someSecret; Max-Age=180; Expires=Sun, 05 May 2024 10:49:07 GMT; Domain=127.0.0.1; Path=/benchmark/crypto-02/BenchmarkTest01824; Secure; SameSite=Strict
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 1100

[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 1098


Cookie BenchmarkTest00108 missing the HttpOnly flag
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:High
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00108
Description:
The HttpOnly flag was missing on the cookie: BenchmarkTest00108. This may allow an attacker to get the cookie information using XSS attacks.
Analyzed Response:

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]

The HttpOnly flag was missing on the cookie: BenchmarkTest01877. This may allow an attacker to get the cookie information using XSS attacks.
Analyzed Response:

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Set-Cookie: BenchmarkTest01877=verifyUserPassword%28%27foo%27%2C%27bar%27%29; Max-Age=180; Expires=Sun, 05 May 2024 10:49:14 GMT; Domain=127.0.0.1; Path=/benchmark/sqli-04/BenchmarkTest01877; Secure; SameSite=Strict
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 1098

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Set-Cookie: BenchmarkTest00085=whatever; Max-Age=180; Expires=Sun, 05 May 2024 10:49:17 GMT; Domain=127.0.0.1; Path=/benchmark/weakrand-00/BenchmarkTest00085; Secure; SameSite=Strict
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Set-Cookie: BenchmarkTest01859=whatever; Max-Age=180; Expires=Sun, 05 May 2024 10:49:22 GMT; Domain=127.0.0.1; Path=/benchmark/weakrand-04/BenchmarkTest01859; Secure; SameSite=Strict
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Content-Length: 1102


Cookie BenchmarkTest01866 missing the HttpOnly flag
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:High
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/weakrand-04/BenchmarkTest01866
Description:
The HttpOnly flag was missing on the cookie: BenchmarkTest01866. This may allow an attacker to get the cookie information using XSS attacks.
Analyzed Response:

The value of the cookie is not protected by HttpOnly flag and hence becomes accessible from JavaScript

Password Sent in URL
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:High
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/ldapi-00/BenchmarkTest00021?username=pppp&password=pppp&BenchmarkTest00021=Ms+Bar
Description:
The application sends the user's password in clear-text over the URL.
Analyzed Request:

Parameter name 'password' was found in the Query, this looks like a field containing password

GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/ldapi-00/BenchmarkTest00021?username=pppp&password=pppp&BenchmarkTest00021=Ms+Bar HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.2; Trident/6.0)



Session Fixation Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:Low
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/trustbound-00/BenchmarkTest00031?username=ee&password=ee&BenchmarkTest00031=my_user_id
Description:
The application does not set a new Session ID in the cookie after what appears to be an authentication attempt by the user. If this was a successful login and the Session IDs are stored in cookies then this application is affected by Session Fixation vulnerability.
Session Fixation Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:Low
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/weakrand-00/BenchmarkTest00042
Description:
The value of the Session ID is the same after what appears to be an authentication attempt by the user. If this was a successful login and the Session IDs are stored in cookies then this application is affected by Session Fixation vulnerability.
Analyzed Request:

The the cookie parameter 'JSESSIONID' appears to contain the session ID value. If this is the login request then the pre-authenticated session ID value is 'AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796'

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/weakrand-00/BenchmarkTest00042 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=AEAC4CAB96B6902A1B50A51ABD5C6796



Information about the Analyzed Response:

The response does not contain any Set-Cookie headers that sets a new value for the Cookie parameter 'JSESSIONID'. This indicates that the session ID value is not changing after authentication.

Session Fixation Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:Low
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/weakrand-00/BenchmarkTest00042
Description:
The value of the Session ID is the same after what appears to be an authentication attempt by the user. If this was a successful login and the Session IDs are stored in cookies then this application is affected by Session Fixation vulnerability.
Analyzed Request:

The the cookie parameter 'JSESSIONID' appears to contain the session ID value. If this is the login request then the pre-authenticated session ID value is '1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745'

POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/benchmark/weakrand-00/BenchmarkTest00042 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Cookie: JSESSIONID=1A07AA987B519672B9A12AC39C315745



Information about the Analyzed Response:

The response does not contain any Set-Cookie headers that sets a new value for the Cookie parameter 'JSESSIONID'. This indicates that the session ID value is not changing after authentication.

SQL Error Messages Found
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Medium
Confidence:High
Found By:Active Scanning

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/sqli-00/BenchmarkTest00434
Affected Parameter:BenchmarkTest00434
Parameter Location:Body
Description:
SQL Error Triggering was identified in the BenchmarkTest00434 parameter of the Body section of the scanned request. SQL Error Messages have been found in the response when testing this parameter. All checks performed to identify SQL Injection returned negative results so the reason for why these error messages appear cannot be determined.
The error messages are:
SQLState
SQLState

XSS Filter disabled
<<<>>>
Type:Vulnerability
Severity:Low
Confidence:High
Found By:Passive Analysis

Affected Site:http://127.0.0.1:8080/
Affected Url:/benchmark/xss-00/BenchmarkTest00030
Description:
The application appears to intentionally disable IE's cross-site scripting filter.
The reason for disabling this feature is usually to support sites that depend on the reflection behavior that Internet Explorer is looking for. However, this feature should only be disabled with the recognition that it will disable defense-in-depth protection for Cross-Site Scripting attacks in Internet Explorer. Best practices should be put in place to eliminate Cross-Site Scripting at the server regardless of if the XSS Filter is enabled or explicitly disabled at the client
Analyzed Response:

HTTP/1.1 200
Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self'; form-action 'self'; default-src 'unsafe-inline' 'un[---- Snipped rest of this header for brevity ----]
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
X-XSS-Protection: 0
[---- Snipped parts of HTTP headers section for brevity ----]
Date: Sun, 05 May 2024 10:47:52 GMT
